awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Trustworthy and Automated Electrocardiogram Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve outcomes for patients with heart problems.  This project will develop an AI solution for the automatic interpretation of electrocardiograms (ECG) to detect and predict irregular heartbeats.  This will benefit patients with cardiac arrhythmias and will reduce spending on cardiovascular disease. 
 
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase (SBIR) I project aims to refine existing deep learning-based detection algorithms, develop methods for the prediction of the onset of cardiac arrhythmias, develop interpretable and explainable tools for clinicians, and develop a web-based software tool for users to develop insights from ECG signals. This project leverages artificial intelligence technologies, including deep learning and natural language processing, as well as signal processing techniques for a trustworthy and automated ECG analysis tool for prediction and detection  The techniques represent multimodal approaches derived from various data sources, including the ECG signals and electronic health record (EHR) documentation of clinician ECG interpretations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The electrocardiogram (ECG/EKG) is a crucial biomedical signal that provides insights into heart function and conditions over time. It is used by medical professionals to diagnose heart arrhythmias, such as ventricular hypertrophy, myocardial infarction, and atrial fibrillation. Timely detection of cardiac arrhythmias is essential due to their potential life-threatening consequences. Atrial fibrillation (AFib), for instance, affects millions of people globally, with over 3 million cases in the U.S. alone. The economic repercussions of AFib are profound with the cost of billions annually in the U.S. Beyond the financial strain, AFib dramatically escalates the risk of strokes, increasing the probability by 5 times. Moreover, projections suggest that its prevalence could potentially double by the year 2030.

In our Phase I project at CardioPhi under the NSF grant, our team embarked on a mission to improve how clinicians analyze heart-related risks using ECG readings. We achieved our main goal by creating artificial intelligence models that can pinpoint and anticipate different heart irregularities within various time horizons with notable accuracy. One standout feature of our models is their ability to give advanced warnings about potential heart incidents based on clear heart readings, making it easier for medical professionals to understand and act preventatively.

To make the findings accessible to the end-users, we introduced a user-centric web interface that presents our ECG analyses seamlessly. Designed to communicate complex statistics in a digestible format, this interface ensures that end-users can easily grasp insights derived from our models. In the face of challenges, like the limited amount of specific cardiac data, we innovated a new machine-learning approach to analyzing heart readings, which has shown promising results. As we continue to refine our methods, we have taken steps to protect our innovations and have submitted our discoveries to a prestigious peer-reviewed journal.

Beyond its clear medical benefits, the broader impact of this development reaches into the realm of healthcare economics and patient outcomes and experience. Early heart-related complications detection often means simpler treatments, fewer hospital stays, and reduced healthcare costs overall. For patients, it translates to faster interventions, better recovery rates, and a significant reduction in the anxiety that comes from late-stage diagnoses.

As for the next steps, we are exploring partnerships and collaborations to collect more ECG reads, experimenting, and refining our software, aiming to bring it to market and make this breakthrough accessible to as many patients and healthcare providers as possible.

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2023
Modified by: Seyed Sajad Mousavi
